sanskrit_verse:
ब्राह्मेण विप्रस्तीर्थेन नित्यकालमुपस्पृशेत् ।
कायत्रैदशिकाभ्यां वा न पित्र्येण कदा चन ॥ २.५८॥
transliteration: brāhmeṇa viprastīrthena nityakālamupaspṛśet | kāyatraidashikābhyāṁ vā na pitryeṇa kadā cana || 2.58||
sph_interpretive_translation: A twice-born shall daily touch water consecrated by a Brāhmaṇa, or by bodily contact with the three sacred fires; never by that consecrated by a Pitṛ.
jurisprudential_principles: Capacity-based responsibility requires alignment with consecrated energy
Restoration logic depends on sustained communion with sanctified elements
Consciousness alignment necessitates proximity to divinely ordained consecrators
executable_legal_axioms: IF consecration_source = pitṛ THEN action_validity = false
supreme_court_application: In matters involving ritual purity and constitutional dharma, the Supreme Court must recognize that only those empowered by Brāhmaṇic authority may confer valid legal-sanctioned consecration. Decisions regarding personal law or sacramental validity shall defer to this ontological hierarchy of empowerment.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that purity arises through consecrated instruments alone. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows that neglecting proper consecration leads to diminished capacity rather than fault. Responsibility lies in aligning oneself with correct causal agents. No punitive consequence accrues—only a natural diminishment in operational dharma until realignment occurs.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Completion Process: Re-establish daily practice under supervision of qualified Brāhmaṇa
Responsibility Assumption Protocol: Acknowledge lapse without shame and initiate purification sequence
Capacity Restoration Mechanism: Perform full-day samskara immersion guided by authorized lineage holder
Integrity Reintegration Pathway: Offer ceremonial restitution using consecrated materials
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source-Authority: This law proceeds from the eternal order of Sanātana Dharma. Justice restores alignment, not punishes error. Consciousness, when rightly consecrated, becomes the highest judge. Thus stands Dharma.
